story: NewsBritain’s richest man plans move to Monaco in a bid to avoid £bn in taxBillionaire Brexiteer Sir Jim Ratclfe, who built up the chemicals giant Ineos, has been working with the accountant PwC on the tax avoidance plan.ShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical CorrespondentNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics video richest-man-quitting-country-john-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news politics  , theme : # , title : Mirror Politics ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLabour has blasted Britain’s richest man over reports he is planning to sht his home and fortune to Monaco in a bid to avoid pound billion in tax. Billionaire Brexiteer Sir Jim Ratclfe, who built up the chemicals giant Ineos, is understood to have been working with the accountant PwC on the tax avoidance plan. Labour’s John McDonnell said: “This is a super-rich person. We’re not talking about someone who’s on his uppers. “For every penny that’s avoided in this way in taxation, what does that mean  It means the NHS doesn’t treat patients, it means our children don’t get the full investment in their education and it means less safety on our streets.“I appeal to people like this - this is a great country to live in, just make your contribution like the rest of us.” Sir Jim was knighted less than a year ago for “services to business and investment.” It comes after Sir James Dyson, another vocal Brexit supporter, announced he was moving the HQ of his vacuum cleaner company to Singapore. The Sunday Times reports that Sir Jims plan would see him and senior executives Andy Currie and John Reece legally share between poundbn and poundbn tax-free, depriving the Treasury of between poundm and poundbn. Sir Vince Cable, the Liberal Democrat leader, described Ratclfes planning as deeply cynical. He said: There are thousands of our constituents who are being bankrupted by HM Revenue  Customs action over small-scale tax avoidance while big fish like Ratclfe are just treating taxation as purely voluntary.   The idea that we should be dishing out knighthoods to people who have no commitment to this country is rather shameful. John McDonnell, the shadow chancellor, said: The greed of these super-rich tax avoiders seems to have no bounds. Dont they realise that every penny they hide away in their tax havens is a penny not spent on our NHS treating the sick, or social care looking after our lonely, isolated elderly, or the education of our children  Meg Hillier, the Labour chairwoman of the public accounts committee, said Ratclfe was in effect sticking two fingers up at the country that had honoured him.  The -year old businessman was named the UK’s richest person in May , after amassing a fortune of pound. billion. He was born in Failsworth, near Manchester, and lived in a council house until he was . He attended Beverley Grammar School in Hull, before graduating from Birmingham University with a degree in chemical engineering in . After working for Esso, he moved into finance, joining private equity firm Advent International in . He ed to the chemicals industry in , when he founded Ineos, now valued at pound billion. A keen outdoorsman, who has made expeditions to the North and South Poles, Sir Jim also founded the charity Go Run for Fun, which encourages children between five and  to get more active by arranging celebrity events. In  he made a pound million donation to the London Business School. And he made waves in  for the tough line he took with workers at Grangemouth in Falkirk, Scotland’s biggest industrial site. After a dispute over the suspension of a shop steward, he closed the plant and vowed to walk away for good unless workers accepted major cuts to their pensions and conditions. And he faced a furious reaction after it emerged he had conducted the operation while holidaying on his superyacht in the French port of La Ciotat. The year after, Ineos benefited from a poundm government-backed loan guarantee to help it build a gas storage tank at Grangemouth. Ineos told the Sunday Times it had  companies in  jurisdictions that regularly paid idends within the group. It added: We currently have more than  major projects, including both acquisitions and new builds, worth over bn [poundm] each. We have just announced a €bn [pound.bn] investment in Antwerp [in Belgium] and the .bn purchase of Ashland composites [a maker of resins for boats] with more to come. Ineos and its owners always fully adhere to all tax legislation and consistently use external professionals to very that all procedures are correct and compliant.

title: facebook social media giants could
story: NewsFacebook and social media giants could face criminal sanctions over online harmIt comes as a new report calls for an independent watchdog for social media and hefty fines for those who fail to act on harmful contentShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical Correspondent:,  FEB NewsFacebook chief Mark Zuckerberg "Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailSocial media giants like Facebook could face criminal sanctions under plans being considered by the Culture Secretary. Jeremy Wright said he would look at all possible options for penalties in the Governments forthcoming White Paper on online harms, as pressure mounted on internet companies to take action to safeguard vulnerable people. It comes as a new report called for an independent watchdog to regulate social media companies, and hefty fines for those who fail to act on harmful content. The Digital, Culture, Media and Sport Committee delivered its final report on disinformation and fake news today , concluding: “Social media companies cannot hide behind the claim of being merely a ‘’ and maintain that they have no responsibility themselves in regulating the content of their sites.” They said this should apply both to harmful material such as self harm images as well as disinformation intended to subvert Britain’s political process.  Tom Watson, Labour ’s Deputy leader and Shadow Culture Secretary agreed, saying: “The era of self-regulation for tech companies must end immediately.“We need new independent regulation with a tough powers and sanctions regime to curb the worst excesses of surveillance capitalism and the forces trying to use technology to subvert our democracy. “Few iniduals have shown contempt for our Parliamentary democracy in the way Mark Zuckerberg has. If one thing is uniting politicians of all colours during this dficult time for our country, it is our determination to bring him and his company into line.”  Mr Wright expects to meet Facebook chief Mark Zuckerberg during a visit to the United States this week.He said there was no doubt internet companies cannot be relied upon to take action themselves. He told the BBC: I think whats important is that we have a system in place that sets out clearly what the responsibilities of online companies are, sets out how we expect them to meet those responsibilities and sets out what will happenthey fail to do so, and the White Paper will do that. Askedthat included criminal sanctions, he said: We will consider all possible options for penalties and its important I think that those companies that we will be talking to and those companies from whom well expect a positive response to this understand that there are meaningful sanctions available to usthey dont do what they should. Thats what I think we owe the families of those teenagers. Mr Wright said the Government would be judged on how well the proposals succeed in making the internet a safer place. Thats what people expect of us, he added.   His comments follow intense pressure on social networks to take action in safeguarding vulnerable people, highlighted by the case of Molly Russell, who took her le aged .Her family found material relating to depression and suicide when they looked at her Instagram account after her death.A White Paper on online harms will be published by the Government by the end of winter setting out expectations for social media companies, followed by a consultation over the summer that will set out new laws that could enforce the removal of harmful content. The DCMS committee report went on to recommend electoral law be toughened up for the digital age to cope with increasing claims of overseas interference in British democracy. And it repeated the committee’s calls for the Government to make a statement about the number of investigations being carried out into Russian interference in UK politics. Committee chair Damian Collins said: “The UK is clearly vulnerable to covert digital influence campaigns and the Government should be conducting analysis to understand the extent of the targeting of voters, by foreign players, during past elections.”

title: pregnant teen universal credit faced
story: NewsPregnant teen on Universal Credit faced starvation - then something incredible happenedJaedyn Overbury and Lizzie Mason were struggling on Universal Credit after moving out of a Birmingham YMCAShareByStephanie BallooMilo Boyd:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video struggling-universal-credit-teen-feared-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest politics stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A teen couple expecting their first baby were fearing weeks of hunger on Universal Credit before something amazing happeed.Jaedyn Overbury and Lizzie Mason, both , hit hard times after moving out of a YMCA homeless shelter and into a house share in Erdington, Birmingham.The cash-strapped couple lived off dry toast for three days after Jaedyn was signed off sick from his job stacking shelves atASDA with General Anxiety Disorder, Birmingham Live reports.The pound they received each month through Universal Credit soon vanished on rent, smart price food, phone top-ups and public transport back and forth to hospital appointments.   With weeks of nothing but a few slices of bread stretching out in front of the engaged couple and their unborn baby, Jaedyn put out a desperate plea to their new community. The response from kind-hearted locals was astonishing. As soon as his request for advice about food banks began to circulate online residents rallied together to donate a huge hamper of food. Where before they had the bare essentials, the couple quickly found themselves with a fridge full of bacon, fruit, soup, pasta, crisps, bread and dozens of tins, as well as eggs, milk, butter and cheese. The pair said the food haul will last them up to two months and will help four-weeks pregnant Lizzie to enjoy a healthy pregnancy.   Jaedyn said: I was amazed by the response we got, we didnt expect it at all. We had food from about three people, picked up by one of the ladies and dropped to us all on the first night that we had put the post up. And then from there to yesterday we have had four more people drop food to us. While doctors have recommended that the teen should not work at the moment, he is still looking for a job to make ends meet.   Jaedyn continued: The universal rate for being signed off is awful to live on so Im still looking for part time work, even when advised by the doctors not to be in work for the time being. I struggle quite badly with Generalized Anxiety Disorder and I also have problems with my chest and breathing which makes physical tasks dficult, still waiting on x-ray and blood results to figure out why my breathing is so limited. I can barely make it up a set of stairs without gasping for air so any physically job wouldnt work. As well as the food the couple received plenty of advice as to which food banks to go to and how to get vouchers.   Jaedyns heartbreaking appeal on the Erdington community group on Sunday, February  read: Me and my misses are new to areaand we have been here for about four months now. We have moved into a house share of four people and unfortunately due to having a shared kitchen keep having our food vanish out the freezer. We have informed our support staff but they can only recommend calling policeWe have completely run out of food and we dont get any money between us until Thursday . We want to know where the nearest food bank is and how to get vouchers for it  My misses is pregnant and I dont want her to go without anything to eat for the next week, possibly month. We are really struggling with finding something to eat. We both dont have contact with family and no friends in the area, its just the two of us.

title: spooky sightings vomiting space truth
story: NewsSpooky sightings and vomiting in space, the truth about le as an astronautAstronaut Don Thomas, , went to space  times in his career with NASA...ShareByemma jones:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsDon launches on his first mission, STS-, on  July  "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailNothing quite prepares you for that first look at planet Earth from space. The first thing that struck me was how thin our atmosphere is.It’s not the sprawling, beautul blue sky we’re used to, it’s paper-thin. Then the blackness of space, darker than you can ever imagine. There isn’t one astronaut who doesn’t have their nose pressed against the window, awestruck. When I was six, on  May , the US launched the first American astronaut into space. My school had us all watching it on a small black and white TV. That moment changed my le forever – I was determined to one day go into space. Space exploration is one of the most competitive careers ever, and when the application process opens every couple of years, only a handful are selected.    A physics degree is the minimum to get in, so I got a masters and doctorate in engineering, but it still wasn’t enough. I was turned down three times. Only when I got my pilot’s licence, learnt to sky e and got a job at NASA did I finally get through. My fourth attempt, at  years old. I’ll never forget the moment I was told I’d been signed up for my first space mission. I was working in Mission Control, talking to the astronauts up in space, when I got the call – I would be in the next mission going up in two years. I hung up the phone and wanted to scream, but I still had another seven hours of work before I could get in my car and really let go! By the time my first flight came along, I’d been training for four years for one -day mission. NASA prepares us for everything, the idea being to have all the experiences on Earth, so there are no surprises in space. We fly in jet aircraft and special planes capable of creating -second periods of zero-gravity. We train underwater for space walks. We also undergo extensive, continual medical checks.   Everyone on the mission is trained to have a unique skill – I was responsible for the science experiments on board Then two astronauts on every mission are ex-military test pilots, responsible for flying and landing the shuttle.Two people are also intensively trained to be able to do everything, in case someone gets sick. But we all have basic knowledge – let’s just say I could land us home, just not all that well! One thing NASA doesn’t want is anyone getting sick. A week before launch we’re in quarantine. We have to eat carefully prepared food, so we don’t risk poisoning.Every person we come in contact with has had a full check – we can’t risk getting a cold.The space sickness is bad enough, which around a third of astronauts suffer from, puking their guts up from motion sickness. You can imagine what vomit does up there… Not pleasant.  Launch morning on my first mission was the most exciting day of my le. I was lying on my back, strapped in on top of a lumpy parachute, where I lay for three hours before take off.Then I heard the countdown, and three big engines started rumbling up to full power, causing the spacecraft and me to shake.At lt off I felt a push, assomeone had their hand on the small of my back, hoisting me up. I was screaming like I was on a roller-coaster because I knew nobody could hear me, not even the seven other astronauts I was going up with.Of course there was some fear, but it’s % nerves and % exhilaration. Not for my we, though, who told me she hated that launch morning more than anything. It takes eight and a half minutes to get into space,  miles above the Earth. It becomes eerily silent once you make it.Then you unstrap yourself and float out of your seat. We orbit the Earth every half an hour, and see  sunrises and sunsets every day. On my first ever day in space, I looked out of the window and a flash caught my eye. Every second it would go, getting closer and closer.I couldn’t believe on my first day in space I’d made contact with the unknown! But my alien turned out to be a chunk of ice that had come off the shuttle and was flashing every time it hit sunlight.Another amazing sight was a giant ball of light flashing past. A shooting star. Of course I made a wish – to get home safely. My first mission was to further explore the effects of zero gravity on liquids and fire. Liquids form perfectly round balls, and fire also becomes either droplets or big fire balls too.We take plants and small animals up to observe how they grow and behave. Since then we’ve done plenty of other experiments.  We work -hour days with - hours sleep , an hour for lunch and dinner, and a free hour for exercise.We have magnetic chess sets, and we love playing human catch – one of the crew tucks themselves into a ball and we throw him to each other.As for human contact, it’s important to have communication with home. Whenever we passed over America, I always felt a million miles away, like I was detached from my le.I could send and receive one short email from my we each day, and once during a two week mission she was allowed in Mission Control to speak with me on the phone. When the mission was finally over, getting back is the easy bit. You slow down, turn the shuttle around, fire up the engines and start falling so fast that you can see flames as the atmosphere hits around , degrees.We landed smoothly and were welcomed with a huge lunch at NASA – lasagne, salad and cookies – before they flew us home.After I’d hugged my we, the first thing I did was order a pepperoni pizza. The space food is bland – by the end of a mission I couldn’t wait to eat good food. There are many amazing things about being an astronaut, but you have to savour every second of space time – during my  years, I only spent  days in space.One downside of being home is flying on a plane is now extremely slow and boring. I resent how it takes me nine hours to get to England from America – it could be done in  minutes! It also ruins space movies. Gravity drove me crazy. Even in the opening scene I was saying, ‘They’ve got that wrong!’ Now I’m too old for space travel and have retired, but I teach children of the wonders of space every day. When you’ve had an adrenaline rush like space travel, it’s hard to know what’s next. My dream is to receive a call from someone who I’ve inspired to follow in my footsteps. Don is an ambassador for Kennedy Space Center Visitor Complex, Florida, the best place on Earth for space . A one-day pass costs from pound per adult pound per child. Also included is the chance to have lunch with a real astronaut. VisitAttraction-tickets-direct

title: 7 things check your wee
story: News things to lookout for in your wee - as they could be signs of cancerProstate cancer is the most common cancer in men in the UK, and while many of the symptoms dont appear for years there are certain things to look out forShareCommentsByZoe ForseyActing Audience Editor:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsIts very important to check for these signs "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailOne in two people in the UK will get cancer at some point in their lives, an absolutely terrying statistic. While many types of the vile disease come with few symptoms, others have signs which can help identy it as quickly as possible. Prostate cancer is the most common cancer in men in the UK. The causes are unknown, but the chances of developing it increase as you get older. It develops slowly, and many men dont see any symptoms for years. It isnt until the prostate becomes large enough to affect the tube which carries urine out of the bladder and out of the penis that some of the tell-tell signs start to appear.  According to the NHS , there are seven things all men should be checking for in their wee which could be a tell-tell sign of the disease.They are:Needing to pee more frequently, often during the night Needing to rush to the toilet Dficulty in starting to peeStraining or taking a long time while peeing Weak flow Feeling that your bladder has not emptied fully Blood in urine or semenThere are a number of tests which can help diagnose prostate cancer, all of which your doctor should be able to arrange. They are a blood test, a physical prostate examination, and MRI or a biopsy. If the disease is caught early it can be treated through radiotherapy or surgery to remove it. Howeverit isnt caught until later it can spread to other parts of the body. Experts dont know why, but prostate cancer is more common in men of African-Caribbean or African descent and Asian men are less likely to be affected.

story: NewsAustralian beaches close after great white shark takes chunk out of surfers legA friend of a victim described how suspected Great White took a big chunk out of his leg and left him heavily bleedingShareByFred Nathan:,  FEB NewsBeaches have closed near Byron Bay in Australia following a shark attack "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBeaches have been closed in the popular Australian surfing paradise of Byron Bay after a shark attacked a man, taking a chunk out of his leg. Sam Edwardes, was surfing near Belongil Beach, around about .am this morning when he was bitten by the toothy predator. The surfer, who was heavily bleeding, managed to fend off the shark and swim to shore while clinging to his surf board. He suffered shocking injuries to his upper thigh, according to eyewitnesses. Members of the public tried to treat Mr Edwardes as he lost pints of blood while they waited for emergency services to arrive.   His flatmate described his horror in graphic detail, explaining how the pair had just entered the water and were paddling out close to shore when the shark struck. He said: “Keen for a wave this morning, went for a surf and had literally only just paddled out of the water. “I was about  metres behind him , he sat up on his board and instantly a shark smashed up from underneath and knocked him clean off his board.   “There was a lot of thrashing and splashing. He started screaming, we didn’t realise until we paddled back to the beach that there was a big chunk taken out of his leg. “There was a lot of blood, a lot of bleeding. The bleeding was pretty bad. We didn’t see the shark but a bloke who was out there earlier said he saw a fin and he reckons it was a juvenile Great White.   “I was freaking. When I heard the screams he was making in the water and then I saw a chunk of his board floating off, that’s when I realised it was pretty bad. “He was conscious but … his eyes were drting around a bit, he seemed a bit dizzy. “He was saying his breathing was labouring … overall I think he was alright, he was just in a bit of shock.”   The attack has prompted surf le-saving crews to patrol beaches around the touristic hotspot of Byron Bay, with beaches having been closed for the past  hours. title: bbc told be brave over
story: NewsBBC told to be brave over PMs threat to scrap free TV licences for OAPsMinsters have refused to foot the bill for the perk — but a joint letter from charities advises the Beeb to stand their groundShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical Correspondent:,  FEB NewsOrganisations have joined together to try persuading the BBC to fight pressure from ministers "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email The BBC has been urged to be “brave” and tell Theresa May to take responsibility for free TV licences for the over-s.But on Sunday ministers refused to accept the poundmillion-a-year cost of the benefit to pensioners. The Government maintains the broadcaster had “accepted responsibility” for the concession. Now, Age UK, the National Pensioners Convention and the National Union of Journalists have written a joint letter to BBC chairman Sir David Clementi. Currently, all households with someone aged  or over are entitled to a free licence, worth pound.. The Tories stitched up a deal in  to make the Beeb responsible for funding the perk from June .   The joint letter states: “The BBC leadership must be brave. “It must say ending free licences for the over-s is wrong-headed and isive, acknowledge funding this welfare benefit would trigger an end to our public service broadcaster as we know it, and say it must now be down to Government to take back responsibility for this benefit.” The letter says a third of over-s are living in poverty or just above the poverty line and the TV is “vital companionship and entertainment”.   But Culture Secretary Jeremy Wright said: “The BBC will have had many years to prepare for this... So our expectation is clear, we expect them to continue with that concession.” A BBC consultation on who should be eligible for the perk closed this week. A spokesman said: “We invited a range of views to help the BBC make the best and fairest decision... “We will carefully consider all the responses and the BBC expects to make a decision by June this year.

title: cooking sunday roast exposes people
story: NewsCooking Sunday roast exposes people to more toxic air than polluted city streetHeating and burning food produces particles that are inhaled and may increase your chances of developing a deadly diseaseShareCommentsByMartin BagotHealth and Science Correspondent:,  FEB NewsYour beloved roast dinner is filling your lungs with toxic air comparable to traffic exhausts, scientists say "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailCooking a roast can expose people to more toxic air thanthey stood on a polluted city street, warn experts. They found fumes from the meal were  times more polluting than a London roadside and  times over World Health Organisation safe outdoor limits. The shock levels were far higher than expected by scientists. Tests detected tiny particles, PM.s, that are inhaled and linked to heart disease, stroke and lung cancer, which contribute to , early deaths in Britain each year. Over a day, in a purpose-built home in Austin, Texas, the HOMEChem project produced and tested meals such as a full English breakfast, a vegetable stir fry for lunch, roast turkey for dinner and pies for dessert.  WHO safe limits of  micrograms of PM. per cubic metre were exceeded for eight-and-a-half hours out of the . Heating and burning during cooking produces particles, with some food producing more than others. A roast turkey dinner saw pollution levels hit  micrograms per cubic metre. The most PM.s appeared to be produced when Brussels sprouts were charred.  A similar cooking style for vegetables in stir fries was just as polluting as cooked meats. Burning fats in meat or adding them to frying and roast pans also gave high levels. Other sources of PM.s were oils left on electric hobs, heated saucepans and open flames on gas stoves. High levels generally lingered for about an hour after the cooker was used. Even putting two pieces of bread in a toaster produced  micrograms which stayed in the air for about  minutes afterwards. Lead researcher Prof Marina Vance, of the University of Colorado, said: “We were all a bit shocked when we saw our first measurement.  This is the most comprehensive ever assessment of chemistry in a home. These high-end instruments have never really been used to detect pollution levels indoors.” Levels detected dwarfed our Government’s Air Quality Index highest warning rating for outdoors. When there are - micrograms per cubic metre the public is warned to avoid strenuous exercise outdoors. The results were unveiled at the shyAmerican Association for the Advancement of Science in Washington, D.C.  Prof Vance said studies are linking long-term exposure to particles with brain ageing and increased stress levels. Leading British pollution expert Prof Ian Colbeck, of Essex University, said: “A roast is one of the worst ways of cooking as regards indoor air pollution. “However once you stop cooking, concentrations shygradshyshyuallyto background levels.” The AAAS also heard that children in homes with vinyl floors had far higher levels of polybrominated diphenyl ethers — toxic, fire retardant compounds — in their blood.   Always cook using the extractor fan The shock findings of the HOMEChem study has sparked an urgent call to families to ventilate their kitchens. Prof Marina Vance said: “We’ve been telling ourselves ‘boil everything, don’t roast’ but roasts are just too delicious.”   The researchers advise while cooking to: open windows always use extractor fans and hobs at the back of the cooker keep your cooker and pans clean of oils heat on as low a temperature as possible and boiling food on electric hobs is best. Prof Vance said: “Use an exhaust hood, try to ventilate your home while you’re cooking. That’s really my prime piece of advice. “Before, I only used the oven hood ventilatorI was cooking something smelly. Now I put it on for everything.”

title: couples dream holiday turns nightmare
story: NewsCouples dream holiday turns into nightmare after travel firms airport blunderMarion and Robert Doogan had saved up for a year for the holiday of a letime to Turkey - but when they turned up at the airport, staff said noShareCommentsByFred Nathan:,  FEB NewsMarion and Robert Doogan have spoke of their shambles holiday of a letime "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA couples holiday of a letime became a case of blunder after blunder when travel firms Thomas Cook and TUI messed up which airport they were meant to be flying from. Marion and Robert Doogan had booked the fortnights trip to the luxury Turkish resort of Antalya a year in advance and meticulously planned every detail.They even paid through the nose for upgraded airport loungers and transfers to make their journey smoother, reports the Daily Record .But the holiday began on a bad note when they turned up at the check-in desk at Glasgow Airport, they were told their flight was from Edinburgh. Marion, , said: “We had tickets which clearly said Glasgow on them. But the girl at the desk shook her head. There were no flights to Turkey from Glasgow for three days.”   Airport staff contacted travel agent TUI, who had booked the pound Thomas Cook holiday. Sheltered housing boss Marion added: “The TUI shop insisted we were departing from Glasgow. Thomas Cook said they had told TUI otherwise. It was a shambles. No one had thought to tell us anything. “So Robert phoned our son and asked him to take us to Edinburgh. “We bundled our cases into our son’s car. We didn’t know whether we would catch the flight or not. “Staff at Edinburgh Airport were supposed to be waiting for us but when we got there, no one knew we were coming.” But Marion and Robert, , an assessor for the Scottish Qualications Authority, breathed a sigh of relief when did did make their flight and it took off for Turkey.   She said: “Our pre-booked seats were gone and there was no airport lounge but at least we were on board.” But further chaos ensued when they arrived in Antalya and were stranded again. Marion said: “We had paid extra for an upgraded private transfer. But there was no one to meet us.” Marion complained to TUI and Thomas Cook again and finally a transfer to the all-inclusive Barut Hemera complex was arranged. But Marion said: “We didn’t get to the hotel until .am when we’d left Edinburgh at .pm. This was hardly the relaxing start to the holiday we had planned.” The confusion continued during their break. She said: “We had no idea whether we were on an Edinburgh or a Glasgow flight home. No one could tell us.”   They flew back to Glasgow and submitted a claim to TUI and Thomas Cook. Marion said: “I wanted a refund for the lounge and pre-booked seats. I also demanded that they cover our outlays and offer something for the stress.” But she called me in when she was getting nowhere. She said: “I have been trying since we got home on September . But they are blaming each other. I am not going to let this drop.” Thomas Cook said they had told TUI about the flight change  months in advance. They added: “We are sorry this information did not reach Mr and Mrs Doogan. It was TUI’s responsibility to ensure the customers were notied.” TUI apologised and said: “We are in contact with them to resolve the matter.”

story: NewsTheres a flat inside the clock tower of St Pancras station - and its incredibleLuxurious hidden pad is a commuters dream - but the price tag may put you offShareCommentsByFred Nathan:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsThe quirky living room is fit for a king - or the wealthiest commuter "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA luxurious pad in the clock tower of St Pancras station is a world away from the hustle and bustle four floors below. A commuter hub with six tube lines, two national rail lines and the Eurostar - not the mention Kings Cross next door - St Pancras certainly is in the heart of London. But hidden away in the clock tower of the famous Victorian building, past the concierge and the on-site swimming pool and spa is a gorgeous flat - and it is now available to be rented out on AirBnb. The  metre high clock tower which the flat sits in, houses the St Pancras Chambers, which was home to the stations railway offices for most of the s, reports My London . It was converted into flats by the Manhattan Loft Corporation between  and , with one recently renovated and transformed into a deceptively spacious, modern rooftop haven.  It contains two double bedrooms, two bathrooms, a kitchen area, living room, and transport links impossible to contend with. The owner of this apartment has spared no expense, restoring the ft high ceiling and Victorian floor tiles to their original splendour and decking out the living room with a grand piano and antique, wooden chess set. Renters can relax in a lavish, free-standing copper bathtub and admire the modern artwork on every wall, or gaze out of the gothic windows onto the London skyline.   If Londons restaurants dont take their fancy, those living there can order room service from the George Gilbert Scott restaurant in the neighbouring five star St Pancras Renaissance Hotel. Guests can also use all of the hotels lavish facilities, and with a spa, swimming pool and gym just down the corridor and a iety of shops and cafeacutes on the station floor, youd need never leave the shelter of St Pancras. Those who venture out of their central London sanctuary can wave goodbye to the -hour concierge and saunter to the car, parked on site in their own private bay. But needless to say, budget-conscious travellers ought to look where. At pound a night and with the flat completely booked out until January , hopeful holiday makers will have to wait their turn or get deeper pockets.  Student, , who has poundk holidays overwhelmed by skint familys amazing gesture  Formerly the Midland Grand Hotel, the St Pancras Renaissance Hotel is the original railway terminus accommodation for the station.It was designed by George Gilbert Scott after he won a competition, and building started whilst the main station was still under construction. The hotel closed in , but the building was taken over by British Rail under the new name, the St Pancras Chambers. The tower underwent a pound million restoration in s, and the hotel was re-opened, with the upper floors converted into  apartments.

story: NewsMan, , just  days from death after horror abuse from girlfriend speaks outAlex Skeel, , had boiling water poured over him, was physically attacked, denied food and kept isolated from loved onesShareCommentsByTom DavidsonOnline Reporter:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsTwisted Jordan Worth banned Alex Skeel from their bed and kept food from him "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man who was tortured and abused by his girlfriend for six years has spoken out about his horric ordeal in a new documentary. The -year-old was just  days from death when help finally reached him, reports the Sunday Express . Worth, , admitted grievous bodily harm and coercive controlling behaviour and was jailed for seven-and-a-half years at Luton Crown Court in April . Worth and Alex met at college in  when they were both  and the court was told from the abuse started early in the relationship.  My toddler son stopped eating and speaking because he watched his dad abuse me  A film about Alexs ordeal, Abused By My Girlfriend, narrated by Alex himself, is on BBC Three tomorrow. story: NewsNew mum, , given nine months to live after morning sickness turned out to be cancerBrave Elizabeth Wagner, from Walton, Liverpool, welcomed her second son, Elijah, into the world just three months agoShareCommentsBySophie EvansEmilia Bona:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsElizabeth Wagner, pictured with her baby son Elijah, has been given just six to nine months left to live "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A -year-old new mum has been given just six to nine months left to live after being diagnosed with a rare and aggressive form of liver cancer . Brave Elizabeth Wagner was dealt the devastating blow just months after welcoming her second son, Elijah, into the world, the Liverpool Echo reports. Her family now fear that the terrible morning sickness that she suffered throughout her pregnancy was actually a symptom of the deadly disease.Her sister Hannah Wagner, , said: She was sick right through her pregnancy but thought it was morning sickness all the way through. We dont know nowthat was a symptom. Healthcare assistant Elizabeth, who also has a three-year-old boy, Ethan, with her partner Jairo, gave birth to little Elijah three months ago.   But days later, she was taken to hospital after developing excruciating pains in her sides. Doctors later told her she had  liver abscesses. And last week, she and her family were given the heartbreaking news that she actually had liver cancer, which was very rare and advanced. They have been told there is nothing medics can do.Now, Elizabeths loved ones are desperately appealing for help in funding a potentially le-saving proton beam therapy treatment that is not available on the NHS.If the treatment is identied as an option for the mum-of-two, she would need to travel to the USA for treatment - at a cost that her family cannot cover. Hannah told the Echo: She means so much to all of us.  None of us want to lose her. Shes the one whos crazy and funny and shes got two boys - she doesnt deserve to lose out on seeing them grow up. Elizabeth, from Walton, Liverpool, works at Fazakerley Hospital. Her family claim her cancer was initially missed by healthcare professionals. Hannah said: She started having pains in her side and it was after she had just given birth and she thought it was something to do with the pregnancy. That was pretty much straight [after having Elijah]. Elizabeth also suffered from sickness throughout her pregnancy. Her sister added: She didnt do anything about it after giving birth and then after a week or so her boyfriend took her to the AE because she was in that much pain.   It was during Elizabeths admission to hospital in December that doctors found  abscesses on her liver, which they opted to try and treat with a course of antibiotics. However, earlier this month, the new mother and her family say they were told that the abscesses were actually liver cancer - and doctors couldnt do anything. Elizabeth had only just moved into her new house with her young family. Devoted Jairo has now had to take on all the responsibilities of becoming a father again - while caring for his partner and making her healthy food. Hannah said: He has been amazing - hes looking after the kids, taking care of her, making her healthy food, he doesnt take his eyes off her. She added that the couple are planning to tie the knot in April.   Elizabeths family have set up a GoFundMe page in a bid to raise pound, to fund her travel and treatment in America. In a post on the page, Hannah writes: I am asking as many people as possible to please give us as much or as little as you can spare. This would enable us to be in a position to try and save my sisters le, we have no other options available to us. Elizabeth is a devoted partner to Jairo and an amazing mum to her two very young boys, she has so much to live for and is ready to fight this illness, we just need a bit of financial help.To visit the familys GoFundMe page or to donate, click here

title: i knew you were gone
story: NewsI knew you were gone. You were with me: Mums devastating letter to daughter year after she was killedLori Alhadeffs -year-old daughter Alyssa was one of  students killed in the Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School shooting on Valentines Day in ShareCommentsByZoe ForseyActing Audience Editor:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news us-news video mums-heartbreaking-letter-daughter-anniversary-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailLast Valentines Day -year-old AlyssaAlhadeff woke up, got dressed, and did her hair and make-up ready for school as ususual. Before she left her mum Lori handed her a gold gt bag containing a pair of earrings, chocolate bar and some hairbands. They both said I love you as Alyssa opened the car door and headed to Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Florida.Later that day a former student opened fire, killing  students and three teachers - including Alyssa.Lori never saw her little girl again.   A year after her death, Lori has penned a heartbreaking letter to her daughter. Mothers know. Intuition prevails, she writes. Mine came as soon as someone told me thered been a shooting at school. I knew you were gone. You were with me. I knew it. She talks about how her daughter wasnt looking forward to Valentines Day as she didnt have a Valentine.   She says it still feels like yesterday, writing: I wish I could take all the bullets for you. I just want you back. She writes about the final time she saw Alyssa, and updates her on all the things her two brothers have been getting up to.Since the horric shooting Lori has campaigned for change and set up the organisation Make Our Schools Safe.She made headlines around the world after she appeared on CNN the day after the shooting pleading with President Donald Trump to increase security in schools.Lori has published her full letter online, alongside a link to her school safety organisations fundraising page , with the title A Parkland moms Valentines Day letter to her daughter.  Loris letter in full Its Valentine’s Day. A day full of love, chocolates and flowers. For me, it is more than that now. Last Valentine’s Day was the last time I saw you. You wore a black and white dress. Your long dark hair dangled. Your makeup looked just right. Of course, your white Converse sneakers protected your feet as you walked in to Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School.Valentine’s Day is now about memories. Today, like all days, I remember. I remember you weren’t looking forward to going to school that day. Like many  year old girls, you wanted a Valentine and were disappointed that you didn’t have one. High school love is magic. I was  once and those butterflies had whirled inside of me too. I wanted that for you. I remember the golden gt bag I gave you that morning. It held a pair of diamond earrings to make you feel pretty, a chocolate bar to make you smile, and hair ties so you wouldn’t ask for mine.   I touched your ears, putting the stems of the earrings through your lobes. You said you were ready to go to school after that. You opened the car door. “I love you,” I said. “I love you, too,” you said.Valentine’s Day. The last time I saw you alive. ****A year has been a long time without you. So much has happened I want to tell you about. I watch your brothers miss you terribly. They want you to know they miss fighting with you. They say thank you for convincing dad to get unlimited WiFi. Dad fights for you every day. He’s your voice.   Grammy has honored you and became a school safety activist. We got a dog! Her name is Roxy and she’s a soccer player, like you. She kicks the ball around the yard, but sometimes puts it in her mouth. And your soccer team...wow, what a group. They wear your number eight on their sleeves and have started using it sideways to honor you. Infinity. Oh, and I found out about the time you jumped off a bridge down by the beach !Alyssa, you jumped off a bridge ! **** There are things I do in your memory that I never thought I could or would ever do.See, a mother’s protective instincts don’t leave when we lose the ones we love. I talk to other moms who have lost children. We talk about you. We talk about their kids. But when we look into each other’s eyes, we see it. A fire. I ran for the school board. I won! I screamed on national TV—words of rage directed at the President! I started a non-profit called Make Our Schools Safe and there is a law named after you in New Jersey--Alyssa’s Law.  **** Mothers know. Intuition prevails. Mine came as soon as someone told me there’d been a shooting at school. I knew you were gone. Rabbi Gutnick said, “Have faith, Lori.” I said, “No, you must start planning now.” You were with me. I knew it.We lost  students and three teachers.  beautul people we, as a community, needed to bury. You were the first. The next day, Rabbi Gutnick presided and hundreds of people came from all over the country. If you remember from Bat Mitzvah classes, shivas last seven days when a loved one dies. In those seven days, I got so many hugs from people who loved you. From family. From people I’d never met. So many that I injured my neck. People, in a sense, loved me until it hurt. ****It’s Valentine’s Day.As I remember you, grief washes over me. But that grief emboldens me to fight for change. I wish I could take all the bullets for you. It’s been a year since I saw you. You, in that black and white dress, those Converse on your feet, and that smile. I’ll never forget that smile. It feels like yesterday. I just want you back. Love forever, Mom

title: royal navy deployed after spanish
story: NewsRoyal Navy deployed after Spanish warship order boats away from GibraltarCommercial vessels have been told to leave the seas around the waters of British controlled GibraltarShareCommentsByNeil Murphy:,  FEB NewsA Spanish warship has ordered commercial vessels away from Gibraltar "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA rogue Spanish navy warship told commercial vessels to leave British waters while they were anchored in Gibraltar. Spanish patrol boat Tornado told two other ships, the Ivor Accord and the Great Victory, to leave the area on the east side of the Rock. The ships were anchored well within British territory when it made the order to leave Spanish waters. The Gibraltar Chronicle obtained radio traffic between the boats, which allegedly told the boats they were “violating the condition of innocent passage”.The Royal Navy’s Gibraltar Squadron despatched two vessels, HMS Scimitar and a inflatable boat to shadow the ship.The Tornado then kept close to the Gibraltar coast line as it sailed out through the straight out of British controlled waters.   A spokesman for the Gibraltar Government told the Gibraltar Chronicle that officials were aware of the incident. “Her Majesty’s Government of Gibraltar is verying every aspect of the incident in order to ensure that appropriate action is taking as soon as possible,” the spokesman told the Chronicle. “Gibraltar VTS ensured that the vessels in question did not act in consequence of the illegal Spanish instructions.” “There is only nuisance value to these foolish games being played by those who don’t accept unimpeachable British sovereignty over the waters around Gibraltar as recognised by the whole world under the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea.” “It seems there are still some in the Spanish Navy who think they can flout international law.” “This probably accounts for the state of extremism of some parts of the Spanish political spectrum these days.”

title: dundee move was easy decision for aberdeens scott wright to make
story: Leaving a squad challenging at the top of the table for one struggling at the bottom may seem like a big decision for any young footballer to make.One that you might need a bit of time to think over.For Dundee’s on-loan winger Scott Wright, however, a phone call to Dens Park boss Jim McIntyre was all it took to convince him to head down from Aberdeen.And just two games into his temporary switch to dark blue, the Scotland U  international is already convinced his snap decision was the right one.“I’m loving it here and all the boys are making me feel really welcome. Now it’s a question of getting settled in as quick as I can and just playing football,” he said.“I had obviously spoken to Derek McInnes and he said to speak to Jim McIntyre before making any decision.“The gaffer at Aberdeen left it up to me.“He told me he’d love to have me still up there butI wanted to go and get games he understood.“So I spoke to the gaffer here on the phone and I loved everything he had to say. I jumped at the chance to come down here.”And the -year-old sees the draws against Hamilton and Kilmarnock since he arrived as proof this is a squad that can pull away from the relegation zone between now and the end of the season.“The only frustrating thing for me so far is that we’ve not taken six points out of six from the two games I’ve been involved in but I think all the fans and us as a team can feel from those performances that we are building momentum.“In the Hamilton game it was a case of everyone trying to get used to each other. A lot of us had only come in right before the deadline and we only really had one training session together.“It was about trying to get to know everyone’s games, their personalities. I think we are all starting to gel now and you can see that on the pitch.“Not having a game last weekend because we’re out of the cup has given us a bit more time to work on that. That gives us a better picture going into the game against Livingston this weekend.”Today’s trip to the Tony Macaroni Arena to face Livingston is a meeting with a team who have taken the Premiership by storm this term but have been struggling for a win of late.Since thumping Hearts - in mid-December, Gary Holt’s team have not won in eight outings. Wright does not see that as a sign this could be an easy  minutes for Dundee.“We have to treat it that every game from now on is going to be a big game for us and this will be.“We know how Livi will be and they will work hard but all we can do is just prepare the way we want to and work on how we can play. Hopefully, that will be enough.“They haven’t won in a few games but it’s a testimony to Livi how many points they have. They started the season so well.”Today, of course, will see Dundee asked to play on Livi’s much-criticised plastic pitch.The debate over their use has surfaced again this week via the PFA canvassing their members for views on them. While Wright is very much in the camp that prefers grass surfaces, the articial surface is not something he’s going to gripe about.“All we can do is get on with it and we are not going to use the pitch as an excuse,” he added.“Playing in Scotland, you get used to them.“However, I think having everyone playing on grass is something that would benefit the top league.“You prepare for a team each week but, for these games, you also have to prepare for the pitch as well.“All we can do as players is give our opinion about them.”

title: gomis set to take over as dundee united target hat trick of wins down at queen of the south
story: Veteran Morgaro Gomis is set to take over in midfield when Dundee United try to make it three wins on the bounce as they head for Queen of the South today.The -year-old is expected to replace Calum Butcher, who will serve the first game of a two-match ban after his red card in the Scottish Cup win at St Mirren last weekend.His second game on the sidelines will be the cup quarter-final against Ross County or Inverness Caley Thistle which has been confirmed for Sunday, March  at pm.The game is also being televised live on BBC Scotland.As well as continuing their recent winning run, the Tangerines will be looking for their third success of the campaign over Queens.To do that, though, manager Robbie Neilson is well aware they will have to keep in-form home striker Stephen Dobbie quiet.His spectacular strike in the cup at Aberdeen on Sunday was the -year-old’s th goal in just  appearances this term.“He has been on fire lately and someone we will have to get to grips with,” said Robbie.“He has a lot of quality, he knows how to score goals.“He’s just a very good player and I think he has the freedom of Dumfries these days. He’s a god down there.”United have their own in-form attacker in the shape of Pavol Safranko.The Slovakian, who’s on loan from Aalborg, has hit the net three times in his last four games.That’s taken his tally so far to  goals and he’s scored on the two previous occasions he’s faced the Doonhamers.“We been playing well and we’re looking for that to continue,” added Robbie.

title: legend maurice malpas reckons january business could help dundee united reach premiership
story: With a total of  appearances for Dundee United, there’s not many better qualied to speak on the state of things at Tannadice than Maurice Malpas.And the club legend reckons their January business has given them “a chance” of promotion back to the Premiership –they can keep displays up for more than  minutes.He said: “The last couple of games they’ve been good in the first half but ran out of steam in the second. If they can get the players bang at it for more of the game I think you have to say they have a chance.“There is a bigger iety of player to choose from now and they have some players who are willing to put a boot in, which you need when games aren’t going your way.“They have a chance of getting up but they can’t drop many points.”As for his own situation, Malpas is quite content looking on from the stands after being assistant to Richie Foran at Inverness last season.Malpas added: “These days I watch United on a Saturday and do a bit of babysitting.“I’ve no desperation to get back in. If something came along I’d consider it but when you’ve been in the game as long as I have you can’t see the wood for the trees. Once you’re out you see the things that really matter in le and I’m quite happy.“I do a bit of coaching over in America a few times a year which gives me my wee fix but I’m quite happy where I am.”

title: livingston may be off form but dundee boss jim mcintyre expects a tough test today
story: Dundee boss Jim McIntyre is taking nothing for granted when his improving team face off-form Livingston at the Tony Macaroni Arena today.The Dark Blues head over the Forth on the back of displays against Hamilton and Kilmarnock that, but for injury time mishaps, would have earned six points instead of two.An injury-time equaliser cost victory at Accies while the chance to take maximum points against Killie last week slipped away when Kenny Miller’s penalty was saved in the fth minute of time added on.Now it’s on to Livi, who’ve not won since before the winter break but Jim believes Gary Holt’s team remain formidable opponents.“It’s natural that at some stage of a season you will have a dip and they’ve still had a brilliant season. They have some very good players,” he said.“The first thing we have to do is try to win our battles but don’t forget they have scored some quality goals, some good team goals.“We have to try to make sure inidually we get the better of them and try to go and create opportunities to win the game.”Dundee go into the clash with controversy over plastic pitches like Livi’s rekindled by a PFA survey showing top-flight players are unied in opposition to them.The manager is also in that camp but hasn’t forgotten that defeat at the Tony Macaroni in his first game in charge was down to what happened in the air and not the surface.That day back in October his team conceded four goals from set pieces.“We didn’t deal with set plays and that killed us. It was an eye-opener that day in terms of what we had to work with,” he said.“There’s no doubt, though, the surface is an advantage. I was the manager of a team, Queen of the South, who had an articial surface andyou train on it every day it’s a definite help.“At the same time I’m not trying to detract from how well Livingston have done because they’ve done exceptionally well.”Dundee are still nursing a few niggling injuries from that Killie draw, but it’s hoped everyone who was on duty then will be available. Midfielder Ethan Robson is expected to recover in time from the groin injury that forced him to miss that game.

title: party goers turning dundee street into bottle graveyard
story: Locals fear streets around one of Dundee’s busiest nightle spots are turning into a “bottle graveyard”.Areas around South Ward Road have been left in a mess in recent months, with revellers knocking back booze on the streets and using electrical boxes as tables before moving on to city nightspots.Pictures taken earlier this week show beer cans and bottles of spirits dumped opposite the petrol station.One local said the area was particularly bad yesterday morning after party-goers had been out on the town.He said: “I came down Thursday morning just before am.“I was greeted with sick, urine, bottles of spirits and empty cans of beer.“It always seems to be worse on a Thursday morning after a Wednesday evening.“It’s a bottle graveyard on the way into work.“I would assume most of the revellers are partaking in student nights out and are trying to save themselves a few quid.“I feel sorry for the street sweepers who need to clean these areas up because it’s a total disgrace.“This isn’t a one-off either as it’s happening every week.“I came down today and it was totally clear, which leads me to believe it’s a problem related to Wednesday nights.”Despite the worries of residents, owners of nightclubs in the area have denied any knowledge of their customers drinking in the streets before entering their premises.The owner of Carbon and Kush nightclub on South Ward Road, Tahir Ramzan, said he was unaware of issues of alcohol being consumed on the surrounding streets.He said: “This is the first I’ve heard about this.“Anything that happens en route to the club is outwith our control.“The problem isn’t directly outside the clubs and might be impacting more on the petrol garage.“We certainly don’t have issues with our customers who come in during the week. They come and enjoy themselves.“Given it is not happening directly outside the club it’s outwith our control.”A spokesman for Club Tropicana and Aura next door urged customers and residents to get in touchthere were any further issues.He said: “We haven’t received any complaints regarding this matter. However, we will investigate with the information you have provided us with.“If anyone would like to get in touch with us simply email info@auradundee.”Dundee City Council had not responded to a request for comment at the time of going to press.

title: young women urged to attend voting event run by dundee womens festival
story: Organisers of a centenary suffrage conference have urged young women to turn out in their droves.Dundee Women’s Festival will run the event on Saturday March  entitled “Why Should I Bother to Vote ” and is stressing that it is aimed at the - age group.Chairwoman Prue Watson, , said: “We want younger people to come along instead of people my age.“They are the future and we also want to encourage them to vote because people have died in the past fighting for this right.“I would tell young women that it is important to vote, you can change things by voting.“We are hoping to have  young people at the event but so far we have only got  registered so there is a real push on to encourage more.“The Scottish Parliament centenary grant has allowed us to host a conference on the fight for women’s suffrage and what our vote means today.“Sofriends, daughters or granddaughters are aged between  and , then sign up and find out.“We will encourage them by looking at the history of women’s suffrage and our political system“There are a lot of very interesting speakers lined up including the author Ajay Close, who is a great writer.“I am sure the women who turn up will be very interested in her talk about suffragettes and what they did in Scotland.“Many suffered terrible forced feeding in Perth prison.”Ms Watson added: “We were awarded £, by the Scottish Parliament to stage the event and it allows us to accommodate  people at the conference which is being held at Dundee and Angus College’s Gardyne Campus.“The event is free and lunch is provided, plus there are workshops in the afternoon.“I am sure it will be a popular day.”The event starts at .am.

story: Celtic midfielder Callum McGregor has applauded the character of the current Parkhead side after their dramatic win at Rugby Park. Scott Brown netted a th minute winner to send Celtic eight points clear at the top of the league and McGregor believes that the timing of the goal owes much to Celtics resilience and determination. As the minutes ticked away in what was a game with few genuine chances at either end of the pitch, the Scotland internationalist insisted that Celtic deserved credit for their never-say-die attitude.

title: Autistic boy leads the way in inpsiring kindness project
story: GABRIEL Erasmusrsquos parents have always believed his superpower was his love for people.The -year-old ndash who is autistic, has dyslexia and learning dficulties ndash was unable to speak until he was five.But he was so fascinated with faces he would smile when touching them.And his proud mum Victoria says he has developed an uncanny ability to feel and absorb the emotional discomfort of others.This desire to help gets his creative impulses flowing.His latest venture, inspired by his sadness for an orphan boy he has come to know in his father Jonrsquos South African homeland, has started a kindness craze.His idea to reach out to this boy with a card to cheer him up has inspired hundreds of pupils to join in.Mrs Erasmus, a hotelier whose portfolio includes the Invernessrsquos Glen Mhor Hotel, said for years the family has been helping orphaned children in South Africarsquos Kwa Zulu region.Four years ago they founded the South African Childrenrsquos Charitable Trust and have visited the area with their four children.Mrs Erasmus said: ldquoGabriel came home from school upset one day. His head teacher had been talking about how to build up resilience.ldquoGabriel told him when he has a bad day, I make him feel better, but his -year-old friend at Ikhethelo lsquodoesnrsquot have a mummy to make him feel betterrsquo.Gabriel started to ldquopanic asking how orphaned children could learn resilience or even know they were loved.Mrs Erasmus said: ldquoBefore I could answer, he was asking for a paper and pen to write a card to tell the boy he was special, that he could get through anything and that Gabriel loved him.ldquoThe irony here is that Gabriel cannot write or read and yet he was doing the only thing he could think of to help. He was prepared to work out how to make  cards for the  children at Ikhethelo.Working with printers the youngster created three cards for his pals at the childrenrsquos villages.And the scheme has grown from there.The family split their time between Inverness and Edinburgh, where Gabriel goes to school and gets one-to-one support for his complex needs.Pupils in two Edinburgh schools, as well as those at Cannich Bridge Primary, are now sending cards to the South African youngsters ndash and receiving replies.Posting costs are met by the Erasmusrsquos charity.Amanda Graham, head teacher at Cannich Bridge Primary, said: ldquoIt makes the children in-volved think about others which is really important.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: Council agrees budget for 2019 20
story: It says thebudget is set to deliver pound. million savings over the next three years with a "Change Fund" of pound. million set aside to help "resource and deliver the change programme".Investment of an additional and recurring pound. million for roads maintenance was also approved, with plans for how this will be spentto be brought to a future meeting of the councils development and infrastructure committee.Members also agreed to raise Council Tax by three per cent.Budget leader, Councillor Alister Mackinnon, said: ldquoOur workforce is vitally important to communities. Not just in the services they provide, but, as one of the biggest employers in Highland, council jobs are fundamental to the sustainability of many communities. So a budget for jobs is really good news for people.ldquoA key element of the feedback we received is that we have many cumbersome, complicated and bureaucratic processes. We need to do things dferently, streamlining processes, be more outward looking and adopt best practice.ldquoAn overwhelming message is that we need to be more efficient. Basically, we need to get a grip on our expenditure. As a result we have been examining every budget line and turning over every stone, to make sure that we are getting the best results from the resources being used and challenging where performance can be improved.ldquoIf you always do the same things in the same way, you will get the same results. It is time to change how we do things and so this is a budget for change."The change fund is an exciting element of our budget strategy and will underpin our programme of change over the coming year.Council leader Margaret Davidson said: ldquoThis is a decent, thoughtful and ambitious budget which will help move us into the future, protecting jobs and services."It aims to set the council on a journey of much needed change. We are all ambitious for improvement and what has struck me is the huge buy-in from all staff in challenging circumstances.ldquoThis budget will enable us to be sustainable and I am really confident that we have the necessary knowledge and expertise in our top team to take forward the change programme that is required.Chief executive Donna Manson added: ldquoThis budget process has been about us being connected. Connected to our communities, to our staff, to our partners, to each other ndash building relationships and enabling better conversations and improved understanding.ldquoI really appreciate the input from staff across the organisation during the whole engagement process, and for some really honest feedback. I am equally delighted with the really positive engagement across the political groups.ldquoWe need to manage all our resources, to redesign, to become more resilient, to be more efficient, to invest in our workforce and to plan for the future. We need to embed effective performance management and effective scrutiny.ldquoThe Corporate Plan will be coming to council in March and this will focus on scrutiny and driving performance. It will underpin the work of the council moving forward, ensuring that we use all our resources to the best effect ndash and the engagement with communities and staff will be a continuing process throughout the year. I look forward to getting back out to see staff from next week onwards.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: Cycle ride aims to help Highlands special needs charity
story: SUPPORTERS of a leline service for children and young adults with special needs are to take part in a sponsored cycle ride to raise desperately-needed funds.The Special Needs Action Projectis facing an uncertain future after Highland Council turned down the charityrsquos annual grant of pound, ndash  per cent of the total running costs of pound,.After hearing the charity might have to close, two members of Snaprsquos youth club decided to do something to help.Dean Stewart and Bradley Morrall, both aged , suggested a fundraiser and as a result, a sponsored cycle ride will be held on Saturday March  at the Highland Cycle Ability Centre at Cantraybridge.They and others aim to cycle  km by completing laps of the track.Deanrsquos mother Carol Macdonald said her son had attended Snap for many years.ldquoIt has enabled and encouraged him and many others to enjoy le, have fun, learn, grow and flourish with many dferent challenges, she said.ldquoSnap is a much-needed leline for children and young adults, families, siblings and carers.ldquoSnap is like a great big hug. It provides warmth, security, comfort, friendship and caring when needed.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: Cyclists gather pollution data in Inverness
story: CLEAN air campaigners have strapped pollution sensors onto their bikes to expose the cityrsquos toxic air hotspots.The Highland Cycle Campaign is working with a student-led research project from Cambridge University to monitor air quality near roadways because of fears official figures are not capturing ldquodangerous levels of pollution.So far six members have used the pound monitors in ious areas including the A trunk road.And there are plans to extend its reach to the rest of the Highlands.Secretary Anne Thomas, who acts as local co-ordinator for Friends of the Earth Scotland, said the devices are showing where the most polluted areas are.She said: ldquoThe first maps show pollution levels on Academy Street and at the Longman roundabout as particularly high.And she claimed that the levels did seem, in some cases, to be breaching standards ldquowhich should have been met in .She added: ldquoIn reality there is no safe level of pollution which is responsible for thousands of premature deaths a year across Scotland.Mrs Thomas hopes the findings inspire more people to cycle as studies show car drivers spend longer in toxic air than walkers or cyclists on main roads.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: Date finally set for demolition of eyesore Eastgate Hostel in Inverness
story: WORK is finally set to start on tackling the fire-ravaged Eastgate Hostel in Inverness ndash almost SIX years after the blaze.A start date of March  has been set to begin the demolition of the High Street building which has been shrouded in scaffolding to the frustration of nearby businesses and community leaders for years.The announcement follows a long-running campaign by the Inverness Courier which has kept up the pressure in calling for action and ensuring the issue has remained in the headlines ndash and not forgotten.A spokesman for the owners said following successful negotiations with a demolition contractor the work would begin to take down the frontage of the building and remove the fire-damaged interiors.It is expected to take up to  weeks.Work would start five years and  months after the blaze in April .Community and business leaders have welcomed the news.Crown and City Centre Community Council chairwoman Pat Hayden welcomed the announcement but wondered why work had not started in mid January as previously expected.ldquoI am sorry to say I will only believe it when the workmen are on site, ldquo said Mrs Hayden who congratulated the Inverness Courier for keeping up the pressure since the building was damaged in April .Inverness Provost Helen Carmichael said: ldquoThis is a key city centre location which has for too long been blighted by scaffolding .ldquoThe reinstatement of the High Street is a signicant improvement and I welcome the commitment made by the owners to invest in this key site,she said.Central ward councillor Bet McAllister said it would especially help businesses in the High Street.ldquoI am also heartened to hear of the ongoing commitment to ensure that a replacement building is constructed at the earliest opportunity, she said.But chiropodist Jim Crawford whose business is nearby remained unconvinced. ldquoThere have been so many  dawns, he said. ldquoIf it doesnrsquot start by March , the council should take it over.A spokesman for the buildingrsquos owners said specialist contractors will initially remove asbestos from the site before the scaffolding is removed.The plan is that each stone for the front will be marked and set aside for reuse in the rebuild which has now been approved.The spokesman said the current contract is for the demolition to facilitate the removal of the scaffolding, but the intention was to rebuild fairly soon afterwards.Monday  Feb  : AM
