story: Organisers of the annual Taste of Grampian event at Thainstone have announced this year#s celebrity chefs.At a special launch event Taste of Grampian chairman, John Gregor, revealed that MasterChef star John Torode will headline the th anniversary event on Saturday, June .Chef John said: “I’ve heard the produce in the north-east is some of the best to come out of Scotland.“I’m looking forward to finding some new food and drink producers and using their ingredients in my dishes on the day.”Joining John on the day will be reality TV star Spencer Matthews, who was a surprise finalist in Celebrity MasterChef last year.He will be demonstrating on the day as well as joining John for the main highlight of Taste of Grampian – a joint demonstration.Completing the MasterChef line-up for this year will be Scotland’s national chef, Gary Maclean who was crowned the winner of The Professionals title in .Gary will be demonstrating with Scotch Beef at this year’s eventand supported by Quality Meat Scotlandwho will be the main title sponsor.Also joining the celebrity line-up will be Helen Vass, who was part of the winning team of BBC’s Bake Off Crème de la Crème in . The award-winning pastry chef will be showcasing her baking skills at several demonstrations throughout the day.Commenting at the launch of Taste of Grampian Mr Gregor said: “This is an unmissable event in the Aberdeenshire calendar.“Whether you are a complete foodie or something of a novice chef, it’s a great way of showcasing an eclectic mix of new and established food and drink producers in the area.“We’re delighted to confirm a stellar celebrity line-up with John Torode, Spencer Matthews, Gary Maclean and Helen Vass and we look forward to celebrating our th anniversary in style.”data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.hawick-news webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Aberdeenshire East MSP Gillian Martin"  Constituents urged to get blood pressure checks viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Early bird tickets for Taste of Grampian  are available to purchase online now at www.eventbrite.

title: pick of the pops at annual clan fundraiser
story: A north-east charity has announced plans for a unique music-themed lunch event, to raise funds for its cancer support services.The CLAN Jukebox Lunch is the first of its kind, where, after enjoying a welcome glass of fizz, guests will be asked to choose their favourite tunes, which will be played throughout the afternoon.The  CLAN Jukebox Lunch will take place on Friday, May  at the Marclfe Hotel and Spa.In , over  men and women attended the annual event, which raised £, for CLAN’s cancer support services.During the afternoon in May, there will be a raffle and auction, live entertainment and a two-course lunch provided by the hotel’s renowned chefs. Guests will also be treated to a unique shopping experience, where local crafts people will showcase artworks, gts and clothing items.The popular fundraising lunch, which is sponsored by BP, promises to be a fantastic afternoon of music, shopping, entertainment and friendship.Steph McCann, CLAN Cancer Support’s Fundraising Team Manager, said: “The CLAN Lunch is one of CLAN’s most popular annual events, and we are excited to be adding a new theme this year where guests can request their favourite songs.“The Marclfe Hotel and Spa is an invaluable supporter of CLAN, and this event, with an even wider range of shopping stalls and entertainment, looks set to be the best yet.“CLAN is enormously grateful to our sponsor, BP, which enables us to ensure that every penny raised during the event will come directly to CLAN, helping to support anyone affected by a cancer diagnosis in the heart of communities throughout north-east Scotland, Moray, Orkney and Shetland."The CLAN lunch is always very popular, so we would encourage people to book their place now to avoid missing out.”Tickets for the CLAN Lunch, which will run from am to pm, are priced at £ each and are available inidually or as tables of , and can be purchased by visiting www.clanhouse.org or via the charity’s fundraising team by calling   or email fundraising@clanhouse.org.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.buchanobserver webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Unison wants talks with the council over the threat to jobs"  Unison seeks talks over council job cuts viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "BUCH | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "BUCH | Article Teaser"

title: the top six questions people are asking google about brexit
story: Heres the answers to your questions:What is the new Brexit Party, which has been supported by Nigel Farage What is the new Brexit Party and how do I join The Brexit Party was launched with the support of ex-UKIP leader Nigel Farage in January and recognised as an official party at the beginning of February . It is a pro-Brexit party. Farage has said he will stand as an MEP under the partythe UK does not leave the EU orArticle  is extended. An official website is coming soon, and you should be able to sign up then, but in the meantime you can search for Brexit Party UK on Facebook.Will my passport be valid after Brexit Theres no need to do anything until your current passport is ready for renewal. British passports will change after we leave the EU, with blue and gold passports making afrom October , but youll still be able to travel on your old burgundy passport until it runs out. If theres a no deal Brexit, youll need to have at least six months left on your passport to travel to an EU country. If you renewed your passport before it expired, then any extra months wont count either - your passport should not be any older than nine years and six months when you travel. What is ERG This stands for the European Research Group, which is a group of pro-Brexit Conservative MPs chaired by Jacob-Res Mogg. It is lobbying on issues surrounding Brexit. The group was in the news as it is expected to rebel against todays House of Commons motion which asks MPs to reiterate its support for renegotiating the controversial Irish backstop.Read more: Will UK workers lose their rights and entitlements after Brexit Will EHIC still be valid At the minute,we fall sick or get injured while visiting the EU, then we can access the same free or discounted medical care that is available to residents of that country. The European Health Insurance Cardproves your eligibility. Regardless of the deal reached, the government will need to renegotiate the reciprocal healthcare arrangements. At the minute, a bill called HealthcareBill is being passed through Parliament to help reach such an arrangement. It is important as the scheme provides healthcare for an estimated , UK expats living in the EU as well as  million UK residents who travel abroad to EEA countries each year Until a new initiative is in place, you should check what the agreement is with the country youre visiting as EHIC may not be valid. Make sure you have travel insurance too .Will I need a visa for my holiday Not for short-term stays for holidays or business purposes. This is providing the UK offers the same deal for EU citizens who want to visit us. We will, however, have to to pay a fee to visit Europe after Brexit. From , youll need to fill in a ETIAS application form so other countries can check youre not a security threat. This is similar to the US ESTA scheme. title: uryside park secures european funding
story: The development of Inverurie#s Ury Riverside Park has taken a major step forward with a funding award of over #,.A total of £, was awarded from the LEADER fund, set up to support rural development, and will be used to undertake a wide range of planting within the site.The contract for the planting has been awarded to Aberdeenshire-based CR Contracting North Ltd, which has already done work around the park.Company Director Chris Rogerson said: “We’re really pleased to have been awarded this contract for planting – we also recently constructed the path network, so we are happy to continue with the further development of the park.“Our plan is to complete the path network, then to plant the wet woodland, grassland and wetland meadow areas.“Assuming the weather is favourable we aim to complete the works by winter next year.”The development of the park is managed by a local charity, Ury Riverside Park SCIO.Trustee of the Ury Riverside Park charitable organisation, Claire Maycock, said: “It’s great to see the area develop.“We recently held a volunteer day and planted , trees, so further planting will really enhance the site and make it feel more like a park.”Chair of the Garioch Area Committee, Fergus Hood, added: “This is great news for the Inverurie area, the development of the park is really exciting, and the award of this most recent funding will help move forward with the plans.”European funding programme LEADER allocates cash grants to projects which contribute to key themes identied in Local Development Strategies, such as connectivity, business competitiveness, the environment and people and place.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: volunteer plea for community companions
story: Royal Voluntary Service is looking for volunteers to become Community Companions, a scheme which offers practical support to older people in Inverurie.Tracey Peden, Community Development Operations Manager at Royal Voluntary Service said: “We are initially looking for one or two volunteer coordinators and volunteers to support the scheme in Inverurie, but there is scope to develop the Community Companions service across Aberdeenshire.“Our volunteers find they get as much out of volunteering as they put in it’s incredibly rewarding for them and they make a real dference to the lives of the people they support.“Those who sign up can choose to dedicate as much or as little time to volunteering as they like and full training will be given.”Community Companions volunteers offer the practical help that can make all the dference to older people and help them retain their independence– from assisted shopping and activity programmes, to enabling them to get out and about with community transport. Volunteers also provide company and companionship, while making sure the older person is safe and well.Royal Voluntary Service is one of Britain’s largest volunteering charities with over , volunteers supporting thousands of people each month in hospitals, at home and in the community.To find out more about becoming volunteer call   or email tracey.hann@royalvoluntaryservice.org.uk.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.milngavieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Level Crossing Manager Michael Burnett, Shaun McCabe, PC Derek Jackson and Lauren McCreedy of Network Rail"  Driving voucher win for Inverurie pupil viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: Caithness to get firts vegan BB
story: A BED and breakfast with a dference is to be launched in Caithness next month.Barbara and Peter Gray, who live in Berriedale, will be opening what is thought to be the first vegan BB in the far north and the venture is already attracting interest online from people throughout the UK.The couple moved to Caithness in September after purchasing a property in the village.They come from Derbyshire but spent some time in Lincolnshire before moving to Golspie and then to Caithness.They say they both like the Highlands and wanted to set up a vegan bed and breakfast here.Barbara explained: ldquoWe saw the property at The Braes in Berriedale was up for sale last summer, put in an offer and it was accepted.ldquoAt present, we have a king size double en suite room but would hope to expand and have two to three rooms later.ldquoAs far as I know we are the only vegan BB in Caithness. I think the nearest one to us may be in Aviemore.ldquoFor a long time we have wanted to provide luxury accommodation and cooking for vegans but we will also show people how to cook vegan meals and may do workshops on an ad hoc basis as well as hosting special s for events such as Valentines Day and Burns Nights.ldquoWe will be open for business in March but are already getting interest online from people in the UK and hope eventually to generate interest in Europe and the USA.Asked what would happensomeone who is not a vegan wanted to stay at the BB, she replied: ldquoThey would have to take vegan food as we do not have animal products on the premises.ldquoWe live a vegan lestyle and would prefer vegans to stay here but they donrsquot have to be vegans.Her husband Peter helps run the business but is also a writer.He has been writing for many years but in  started work on a series of crime fiction books whose main character is Detective Inspector James Avalon. The police officer is based in Inverness but travels throughout the Highlands.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: Call goes out for transport review in Thurso
story: A COMPREHENSIVE transport review is required in Thurso, according to a local Highland councillor.Karl Rosie made the plea this week after the issue of speeding and parking was raised at a meeting of the local community council.Chairman Mike Potts noted that a  mph restriction is planned for large sections of Wick and wondered what was happening in Thurso. He said some areas of the town, such as Shore Street and Upper Ormlie, had been designated as one-way streets some time ago but this had not been implemented. "That needs to be corrected," he said at Tuesday nights meeting.Mr Potts and other community councillors felt something had to be done to address the issue of speeding and one suggestion was for more sleeping policemen to be installed in problem areas of Thurso.Councillor Rosie, who represents Thurso and Northwest Caithness on Highland Council, said what is needed is a transport review which can take a comprehensive look at the issue. "We need a strategic look at the whole thing ndash something which covers transport management and pedestrians," he said.However, community councillor and former police officer Bert MacLeod urged caution. He said: "You need to be careful you dont go overboard with this  mph limit. Modern cars can stop quicker than vehicles did in the past. We need to be sensible."Mr Potts claimed "some of the driving in Thurso is abysmal".Mr MacLeod replied: "Why should you and I be affected because someone drives like an idiot "He also pointed out there are problems with installing sleeping policemen on roads. New laws have been introduced as cars have been damaged by them, he said."It is not just a case of putting them down," stated Mr MacLeod. He argued that enforcement is the key to tackling the problem."If you had a traffic warden in each town again that would help," he added.Community councillor Colin Johnston said something should be done to address the issue of traffic and parking in the town.Struan Mackie, another Thurso and Northwest Caithness Highland councillor, stressed that it takes time to process traffic orders and pointed out that the mph plan for Wick began over two years ago.He also pointed out that the county is going to get traffic enforcement officers which should help deal with some of the parking issues.Mr MacLeod commented: "You have got to watch you do not overdo these things."But Mr Potts said: "Parking has been an issue for a long time. It is up to us to keep fighting. There is parking available in the town so the problem can be overcome. That should be our war cry all the time."Monday  Feb  : AM

title: Flexibility plea on new GP deal
story: THE problems facing GPs in Caithness have been outlined to Scotlandrsquos health secretary Jeane Freeman by two north MSPs.Rhoda Grant and David Stewart.Labour representatives for the Highlands and Islands, met with Ms Freeman to express their concern about the new GP contract and the impact it could have on rural and remote areas.They were accompanied by Phil Wilson, a professor of primary care and rural health at the University of Aberdeen and a GP in Inverness.Also present was a Dingwall GP Miles Mack.Mrs Grant asked Ms Freeman for the face-to-face meeting at the Scottish Parliament and highlighted issues which GPs across the Highlands and Islands have raised with her and Mr Stewart.The doctors told the minister that five of the  permanent GPs in Caithness are likely to retire in the next five years.Ms Freeman heard that since  almost half of all permanent GP posts in the county have been vacant and partially replaced with short-term locum provision.Three practices have ceased to be independent contractors and have been taken over by NHS Highland.Concerns were also raised about the capacity for undergraduate teaching and the effect on retention and recruitment of GPs in remote areas.Doctors have told the MSPs that the new contract fails to recognise the workload in rural areas where surgeries deal with a far greater range of medical problems, including emergencies that would be dealt with in hospitals in urban areas.Mrs Grant said: ldquoThe main concern is that whatrsquos on the table with the new contract is an urban model and this just doesnrsquot suit remote and rural areas.ldquoGPs are worried it will cause poor continuity of care for patients and that procedures currently performed at surgeries are being centralised ndash for instance for blood tests or vaccinations.ldquoThis will inevitably inconvenience patients and worsen health outcomes by raising barriers to care.ldquoThe contract states that other healthcare professionals will be employed to deal with these extra tasks ndash but with rural GP posts remaining unfilled, and shortages of nurses in many areas, how can we expect to find these extra people in our out-of-the-way places ldquoThere must be flexibility for GPs to retain the old system of care.The new contractrsquos funding formula has been based on the number of appointmentsand does not take account of the issues faced by rural areas such as patient and doctor travel.ldquoGPs in our region cannot wait for another three years to see some movement on this and Irsquom hopeful that the health secretary will find a suitable way forward.At the meeting Ms Freeman said she had ldquogenuinely taken the issues seriously and discussion would continue with colleagues. Mrs Grant was promised an update in two months.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: Plans to tackle Wick town centre parking hailed as very good news
story: Local Highland councillor Andrew Sinclair said he welcomed the proposals outlined in a traffic order as they give the local authority greater powers to deal with what has been a contentious issue for many years.Many other areas of Wick would also be subject to restrictions.Councillor Sinclair, who represents the Wick and East Caithness ward, said: "I think this is very good news for the town. We have been calling for more parking enforcement in Wick for a while now."High Street and Bridge Street are far too regularly packed with cars parked where they shouldnt be. Its an issue that has been raised time and time again by both drivers and pedestrians. Some people think they are above the rules and for too long theyve got away with it."He added: "Under the current proposals Bridge Street and much of High Street will essentially become double yellows, meaning no parking at any time. This should also help stop the constant issue of people selfishly parking in areas like the Market Square."The parking bays there are intended only for those who are disabled badge holders but these rules are often ignored by people who just canrsquot be bothered walking."Councillor Sinclair said the order would give council officers the power to enforce parking restrictions once they receive the required training but, initially, existing enforcement staff would carry out the work."We should expect a much more regular presence than under the old system," he said. "The discussions Irsquove had with the officer responsible for parking have been extremely encouraging."Having an enforcement officer in the town for regular and random visits is a great start butthe situation doesnrsquot improve we will still be pushing to get someone in this post locally to clamp down on rogue drivers."He explained that in Inverness several council employees have been trained to undertake parking enforcement duties as well as their day-to-day jobs. "There is no reason why the same couldnrsquot be done up here. If these orders get the go-ahead, and I am confident they will, then I hope we will begin to see a dference in peoples behaviour."The Caithness civic leader, Councillor Willie Mackay, also backed the plan. "It is a fantastic idea but it is the enforcement that is the key to the success of this," he said. "If we can get enough staff trained up to act as traffic wardens ndash and I am pretty sure we can ndash then their presence will deter bad parking."Parking in the centre of Wick has been a contentious problem for some time and has often been raised by the local community council and others. If this is approved, it will make a massive dference to the town centre, although there will always be some motorists who will take a chance and park there."However, Councillor Mackay has misgivings about the extent of the restrictions planned for other parts of Wick.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: Prince Harry set to attend Mey games
story: THE Mey Highland Games is going to ldquoput Caithness in the global spotlight, according to its organiser Captain Richard Otley, after Prince Harry announced he would attend the event this year.Rumours were re last year that Harry and his we Meghan would attend the special event which included para-athletes for the first time but when the royal retinue appeared at pm there was no sign of the couple.Capt Otley believes that the information released over the weekend to the media about Prince Harryrsquos attendance may have come from Buckingham Palace itself. He was unable to confirmMeghan would attend along with her husband, but said it would be ldquotruly fantastic for Caithness and help put it on the mapthe royal couple turned up.The Duke and Duchess of Sussex will welcome their first child this spring.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: This weeks Caithness Courier
story: Due to circumstances beyond our control, this weekrsquos edition of the Caithness Courier wonrsquot be in the shops until Thursday morning. We apologise for any inconvenience but this was due to a combination of problems with our contract printers and distribution partners.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: Trailblazers on right path
story: MEMBERS of Wick Paths Group joined forces with Friends of the John OGroats Trail to improve a path used by walkers visiting the Castle of Old Wick.They got stuck in to the task of upgrading the narrow, muddy and uneven section from the old rle range to the field at the Grey Bools. The path had been scraped out in advance by Nordwall Landscaping to a width of . metres and some  tonnes of quarry gravel had been purchased and delivered to site.On the work day  volunteers turned out to help and they were grateful for the heavy machinery loaned by Hugh Simpson , M M Miller and Graham Begg. The gravel was laid in just under three hours and has resulted in a much-improved route.Wick Paths Group chairman Allan Tait said: "We are very grateful to all the volunteers who turned out to help, to the landowners for giving permission and to the local businesses for lending their equipment. The path is very popular with local people for walking and running as well as the increasing use by those walking the John OGroats Trail."This section of path is now immensely better than it was and I hope it will encourage many more people to come out and walk the route."Jay Wilson, chairman of the John OGroats Trail group, said: "Im very pleased to see a great turnout of Wick volunteers to build a path for the town that also forms part of the overall John OGroats Trail."Monday  Feb  : AM

title: We have saved part of our identity
story: THE Dunnet and Canisbay area would have lost part of its identityits community council had been scrapped due to boundary changes, vice-chairman Bill Mowat has said.He welcomed last weeks change of heart by Highland Council and said he was very pleased the body had been saved.Under the proposals, Dunnet and Canisbay would have been linked with Castletown and Bower community councils.Mr Mowat said the area would have lost part of its identitythe plan, which would also have seen the demise of Sinclairs Bay Community Council, went ahead.Details were reported in the John OGroat Journal last Friday."Community councils are of real value when you have got a single-tier council and you dont have a councillor representing the area," Mr Mowat said. "We are very pleased with the outcome which is a small victory for localism."We are relieved we are to continue. There was an indicationthis proposal was forced through most members would not have bothered to continue attending meetings."Mr Mowat pointed out that Canisbay and Dunnet are historic settlements based on a crofting background and said that would have been lost under the plan. "We are delighted we are to continue. This decision keeps our identity in this north-east corner which goes back to the end of the th century," he said.He stressed there had been strong opposition to the plan and added: "It is hardly our fault , as is being claimed, some neighbouring community councils may not be ing as well as some observers might desire. Dunnet and Canisbay should not be punished for this."Mr Mowat explained that Highland councillor Andrew Sinclairhad made the case for retention as he is the current local authority representative on Dunnet and Canisbay Community Council. Councillor Sinclair made a similar plea to retain Sinclairs Bay Community Council whose future was also threatened. Part of its area would have been linked with Wick.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: Wick Francis Street Club placed in liquidation
story: WICKS Francis Street Club has been placed in liquidation, it was confirmed on Thursday.According to provisional liquidator Iain Fraser, a partner with FRP Advisory, the decision was made following a decline in membership, rising costs and unsustainable cash-flow problems. The club ndash founded in the s as a British Legion ndash has now closed and six staff have been made redundant.Mr Fraser said: "The Francis Street Club has been a landmark social, entertainment and sports venue in Caithness for nearly  years. Sadly, the club has been suffering severe financial problems and liquidation was the only option available to the committee."We are working closely with the relevant agencies, including the Redundancy Payments Office, to ensure the staff receive as much support as possible. We are now offering the assets of the business for sale, including the building, fixtures and fittings, and would urge interested parties to contact our Aberdeen office as soon as possible on   ."The Francis Street Club started was a long-established social, entertainment and sporting venue which attracted some well-known names through its doors, including former world snooker champion Stephen Hendry who staged an exhibition match there.It served as a social club and ran both football and darts teams, both well supported by members.It also operated as an entertainment venue, with music and entertainment acts from across the country putting in appearances to local acclaim.The premises closed last month. At the time, a statement issued by the club said: "It was decided by the committee to close the Francis Street Club and Institute Limited at midnight on Wednesday, January , ."A note subsequently posted on the door read: "We have ceased trading from immediate effect at these premises the Francis Street Club Wick. All other details will follow in due course."Monday  Feb  : AM

title: Wicks Francis Street Club closes
story: Wick institution the Francis Street Club has been forced to close due to financial dficulties. ldquoIt was decided by the committee to close the Francis Street Club and Institute Limited at midnight on Wednesday, January , , the spokesperson, who did not wish to be named, said.A note subsequently posted on its door read: ldquoWe have ceased trading from immediate effect at these premises the Francis Street Club Wick. All other details will follow in due course.The building first opened as a British Legion in the s, and remained a popular focal point for the community.It served as a social club and ran football and darts teams ndash both well-supported by members.It also operated as an entertainment venue, with music and entertainment acts from across the country putting in appearances to local acclaim.One famous occasion took place in  when Councillor Willie Mackay was able to persuade top darts players Jocky Wilson and Eric Bristow to play an exhibition match ndash a fixture Scotsman Wilson won.However, it is expected that such nights will now become a thing of the past.It is not known what the future of the building holds, orany parties are considering taking the club over.The spokesperson stressed the committee was ldquovery sad the club had to close.Monday  Feb  : AM

title: blocking the bus in the hope
story: Police Scotland and Orkney Islands Council are asking drivers to ‘think bus’ when leaving vehicles in St Margaret’s Hope.The X service is frequently prevented from travelling through the village when stationary cars and vans block the narrow entrance to the Back Road from Pier Road and Cromarty Square.“If the bus can’t travel along the Back Road it has to take the new road instead and passengers waiting in the village miss their bus,” said East Mainland, South Ronaldsay and Burray councillor, Steve Sankey.“It’s a growing problem and something bus users and the local community council have raised with me. People expect a reliable service and I can understand their frustration. We’re joining with the Police in asking drivers not to block the way into the Back Road and find somewhere  to park that doesn’t affect the bus.”Chief Inspector Matt Webb, Police Scotland Area Commander for Orkney, said: “We will take actionvehicles are left in ways which restrict the passage of the local bus service.“We would rather not do thatpossible # and I would encourage drivers to be considerate and play their part in making sure buses can move freely through the narrow streets of the village.”If you have any comments or feedback on bus services, please contact the Transportation Team at the Council at transport@orkney.gov.uk or  . title: bus feedback events to return
story: Following the success of the event held in February , Bus Users Scotland willto Orkney this month to run another “Your Bus Matters” event to hear feedback on the bus services on the island. The events are open to everyone and will be held in Kirkwall and Stromness.The events give everyone the opportunity to provide feedback on what is working and what doesn’t about the local bus service. We were really pleased with the engagement at our event last year and look forward to hearing from more of the locals on the bus services on the island.”The two meetings will take place, later this month. Firstly, at Kirkwall Travel Centre on Monday, February , pm-pm, and then in Stromness on Tuesday, February , am-.pm.David Liston, managing director for Stagecoach North Scotland added: “We always welcome feedback on the services we provide and there is no better way to gather this than to host an event in partnership with Bus Users Scotland.#The feedback we received last year really helped us to develop improvements across the island demonstrated by the enhancements we made to services throughout the summer in . title: council issues kirkyards apology
story: Orkney Islands Council has made an official apology following public concern about the way the county#s kirkyards are being managed.Distraught families and dismayed public officials have spoken out in recent weeks, after a scheme to improve the safety of cemeteries triggered reports that headstones were being laid flat without relatives being notied.Last week, a council insider told The Orcadian that — in failing to contact families — the council was disregarding government guidelines on cemetery maintenance.“It says it’s good practice to inform the families and give them an opportunity to repair the memorial, and that’s just not being done at all,” the inside source said.The Orcadian also heard from Stewart Spence, whose father#s headstone had been laid down in the Sandwick kirkyard with no notication from the council. This was despite the fact that the name and address of the person they needed to contact — his mother Edna — was engraved on the memorial.#Vandals couldn#t have done a better job,# he said.Following this wave of public concern, OIC convener Harvey Johnston and chief executive Alistair Buchan have now released a statement apologising for the concern and upset that this project has caused.#Following a tragic accident involving a young child at a Glasgow cemetery, the Scottish Government asked councils to carry out detailed inspections in the interests of public safety,# they said.#We therefore engaged in the kirkyard safety programme for all the right reasons, but recognise that the process we have followed needs to be improved. It was never envisaged that the resulting work would leave kirkyards in the condition they are in. We are sorry about the concern and upset this has led to.#As a caring organisation, responsive to public concern, we will restore kirkyards to the condition people would expect. We will also consider how best to contact and discuss the remedial work required with those concerned. People’s safety is an important concern for us and we will continue to carry out headstone inspections. As at Warebeth , we will use blue pegs to mark stones identied as being unsafe and highlight these to local community representatives.#These stones will not be touched until we publicise the inspection results and give relatives the time they need to discuss with us any work they might wish to carry out themselves.#The statement also confirmed that further updates from the council will be provided further updates over the weeks ahead.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: interactive hie roadshow comes to orkney
story: newsInteractive HIE roadshow comes to OrkneyFebruary ,  at : pm vw, px"  Starting here in Orkney this week, Highlands and Islands Enterprise is hitting the road to teach people how to outsmart online criminals and spot cyber threats.The free Cyber Sense on Tour workshops will visit businesses and communities throughout the Highlands and Islands using fun, interactive games to allow participants to get under the skin of hackers and learn the tricks of the trade.The tour starts in Orkney with two events, the first at Orkney Library this Tuesday, February , and the second at the NorthLink ferry Hamnavoe at the Stromness terminal on Wednesday.The interactive experience is open to all and will use innovative technology to create an immersive ‘point of view’ exercise, were participants can take the role of an employee, a cyber security professional and even a hacker to learn the tricks of the trade.Concepts such as ‘phishing’ will be explained and audiences will be taught to spot scams, dissect spurious emails and prevent hackers taking over their online lives.Working in collaboration with the National Cyber Security Centreand supported by the Scottish Government, the Cyber Sense sessions will provide a memorable and engaging way to discover how everyday actions can help protect people and companies from these evolving cyber dangers.April Conroy, project manager at Highland and Islands Enterprise, said: “As the way we work and live becomes more integrated online, it can be easy to take for granted how much important information we upload to the internet. Whether it’s our personal information on social media or important financial details, it’s vital that we’re aware of how to keep our safe and secure from cyber criminals.”“By really getting under the skin of these hackers, our Cyber Sense workshops can point out how to understand how these iniduals work. Through the games we’ve designed, attendees will be able to competitively play roles on both sides of a cyber-crime. This offers a unique perspective that can show just what preventative measures can be taken to outsmart these online criminals.”To learn more about the Cyber Sense on Tour event and to book a free place, visit www.hellodigital.scot cyber-sense- copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: in the footsteps of dr john rae
story: Next month will see a group of intrepid adventurers undertake a -mile mission in the Canadian Arctic, retracing the footsteps of one of Orkney#s most renowned, yet also overlooked, sons — Dr John Rae.The Arctic Return expedition will see a four-man team set off from Naujaat — also known as Repulse Bay — in late March, aiming to retrace the footsteps made by the surgeon, explorer and surveyor in .It was on that expedition that the explorer finally discovered an open channel to the east of King William Island in the high arctic. Known today as Rae Strait, it was the missing link in what would become the first navigable Northwest Passage.He also reported back on the ill-fated Franklin expedition, reported evidence of cannibalism — findings which were effectively rejected by the then establishment, and which led to Rae#s achievements being almost completely ignored.The modern-day team, who hope to raise further awareness of these achievements, will be led by Scottish-born and Canada-based expedition leader David Reid, with Scotland also represented by Broxburn-based former Royal Marine Richard Smith.The team will also include two Canadians — adventure film-maker Gerry Tutte and adventurer Frank Wolf.Over  years later and supported with modern-day kit from outdoor specialists Tiso, the explorers are hard at work preparing for the physical and mental challenge of hauling kg sledges for nine hours daily and for up to  consecutive days.Their route will cover undulating, windswept tundra, river valleys and sea ice during what can be the coldest time of year.The Arctic expedition will finish once the four explorers have finally reached Gjoa Haven on King William Island.Mr Smith said: #The Arctic Return expedition will be extremely tough but ultimately our aim is to raise awareness fo the exploits of John Rae and to help restore his rightful place as one of the greatest Scottish explorers in history. It is also our hope that this awareness will inspire the public to support fundraising efforts by the John Rae Society, to restore Rae#s birthplace at the Hall of Clestrain in Oprhir.The team have said any addition funds raised are to be used to produce a documentary film and book about the le and exploits of Rae, the expedition and the history communities, culture and wildle of the Arctic.The public will be able to track the team#s progress at their official website and through social media.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. story: Orkney#s biennial Youth Conference, held at the Kirkwall Town Hall yestrday, organised by the OIC#s Community Learning and Development Service, brought together  young people from across Orkney to take part in workshops and hear from keynote speakers on a range of issues.The conference was opened by council Convener Harvey Johnston, who said he was truly delighted and privileged to be at the conference, amongst Orkney#s young people.He continued: #Our young folk are Orkney#s greatest asset and I#m expecting great things from you all. Not just today at this conference, but in your lives to come.#Taking to the stage next was keynote speaker John Loughton. John is a high profile and award winning global youth leader, social entrepreneur, campaigner and leadership speaker. He is founder and CEO of global leadership company DareLead. In  he was elected the youngest ever Chair of the Scottish Youth Parliament.On the back of yesterday#s Orkney Youth Conference, local folk in Orkney who work with children and young people, are gathering today for the third Growing Up in Orkney conference.Today’s conference gives them the opportunity to share and learn from each other as well as find out what’s working well in our communities. It’s also about learning from others and exploring practice further afield and deciding what to stop doing, what we should be doing more of and what we should start doing.Delegates will take part in a range of workshops and hear from keynote speaker Dave Clubb. title: power cable repairs completed
story: Repairs to a faulty power cable, which links Orkney with mainland Scotland, have been completed and the cable has been put back into use.SSEN have said the cable was put back into service on Sunday evening and has been under normal operation since then.Prior to repairs being completed at Rackwick Bay, Hoy, a spokesman from the energy company said an investigation had shown the damage to be located at a section of the Pentland Firth East cable, near the shore at Rackwick.The spokesman said there was no impact to their customers as a result of the fault and contingency measures were put in place.SSEN also reported that, as part of its subsea cable inspection and replacement programme, a project to progress an end-to-end replacement of the Pentland Firth East distribution cable is at #an advanced stage of development#, with cable installation and commissioning due to take place in autumn next year.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: team appointed for 4 5m north isles landscape partnership scheme
story: The North Isles Landscape Partnership Schemeteam is now up to full strength with the appointment of three new staff members.Anne Bignall, Valerie Dawson, Claire Wilson and programme manager Andy Golightly will work with communities on the North Isles to deliver projects that will promote the heritage, landscape and culture of the area.Working with the communities on the North Isles the NILPS will deliver projects that will promote the heritage, landscape and culture of the area.Funded by the Heritage Lottery Fund, the scheme will support Orkney’s North Isles through the delivery of a number of projects that includes traditional skills training, educational programmes, wildle recording and enhancement of isles heritage centres amongst others.The programme will invest £. million in the North Isles and the project will run until .Mr Golightly said “It’s great to now have the team in place so we can concentrate on delivering the projects in the isles, a lot of work has been done getting to this point and now the focus will be working with the isles communities to start getting things done on the ground.#One of the first things that will be available is the North Isles Landscape Partnership Heritage Grants. Small grants will be available that contribute to the aims and objectives of the NILPS programme. Groups and organisations can apply for grants of up to £ to support projects, activities and events in the isles.Valerie Dawson, NILPS project officer added: “The Heritage Grants are open to applicants now and we would encourage any not for profit organisations, with any ideas related to heritage, that might require funding to contact us to seewe can help.”The project team can be contacted on or email the North Isles Landscape Partnership scheme or visit their website www.nilpscopy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: Black Isle swimming pool is not yet sunk say supporters
story: DETERMINED campaigners fighting for a swimming pool dedicated to a fast-growing area of Ross-shire have succeeded in a last-ditch bid to keep the dream alive.The Ross-shire Journal last November told how activists behind a -year drive to establish a pool serving the Black Isle issued an appeal to a new generation to either take the plunge and get involved or see it wound up.The Black Isle Swimming Pool Foundationhas raised more than pound, and won planning approval for a new-build in Fortrose next to the existing leisure centre and secondary school.With anumber of BISPF stalwarts no longer able to continue driving the project, chairman Roy Sinclair appealed to Black Islers to grasp the nettle or wind up the foundation.A make-or-break project strategy meeting in Fortrose has seen a fresh commitment to push forward with a number of avenues to be investigated. These include:* A possible community buyout of the Black Isle Leisure Centre run by High Le Highland for Highland Council.* Appointing a business consultant to update the  business plan and probe funding applications.* Appoint a design team by competitive tender to revise the building plans and invite tenders.It was noted that the Black Isle remains a growing area with future housing and an expanding population.While a lottery bid for pound million towards the estimated poundm cost of the scheme failed back in , negotiations with the Scottish Land Fund via Highlands and Islands Enterprise to consider developing the project as a community enterprise company have continued.Mr Sinclair said: "A unanimous positive attitude was evident at the meeting which allows further progress to be made to develop this very important project for the benefit of folk on the Black Isle and beyond."A follow-up meeting is planned later this month.Whats your view  Email newsdesk@spp-groupMonday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Council agrees budget for 2019 20
story: It says thebudget is set to deliver pound. million savings over the next three years with a "Change Fund" of pound. million set aside to help "resource and deliver the change programme".Investment of an additional and recurring pound. million for roads maintenance was also approved, with plans for how this will be spentto be brought to a future meeting of the councils development and infrastructure committee.Members also agreed to raise Council Tax by three per cent.Budget leader, Councillor Alister Mackinnon, said: ldquoOur workforce is vitally important to communities. Not just in the services they provide, but, as one of the biggest employers in Highland, council jobs are fundamental to the sustainability of many communities. So a budget for jobs is really good news for people.ldquoA key element of the feedback we received is that we have many cumbersome, complicated and bureaucratic processes. We need to do things dferently, streamlining processes, be more outward looking and adopt best practice.ldquoAn overwhelming message is that we need to be more efficient. Basically, we need to get a grip on our expenditure. As a result we have been examining every budget line and turning over every stone, to make sure that we are getting the best results from the resources being used and challenging where performance can be improved.ldquoIf you always do the same things in the same way, you will get the same results. It is time to change how we do things and so this is a budget for change."The change fund is an exciting element of our budget strategy and will underpin our programme of change over the coming year.Council leader Margaret Davidson said: ldquoThis is a decent, thoughtful and ambitious budget which will help move us into the future, protecting jobs and services."It aims to set the council on a journey of much needed change. We are all ambitious for improvement and what has struck me is the huge buy-in from all staff in challenging circumstances.ldquoThis budget will enable us to be sustainable and I am really confident that we have the necessary knowledge and expertise in our top team to take forward the change programme that is required.Chief executive Donna Manson added: ldquoThis budget process has been about us being connected. Connected to our communities, to our staff, to our partners, to each other ndash building relationships and enabling better conversations and improved understanding.ldquoI really appreciate the input from staff across the organisation during the whole engagement process, and for some really honest feedback. I am equally delighted with the really positive engagement across the political groups.ldquoWe need to manage all our resources, to redesign, to become more resilient, to be more efficient, to invest in our workforce and to plan for the future. We need to embed effective performance management and effective scrutiny.ldquoThe Corporate Plan will be coming to council in March and this will focus on scrutiny and driving performance. It will underpin the work of the council moving forward, ensuring that we use all our resources to the best effect ndash and the engagement with communities and staff will be a continuing process throughout the year. I look forward to getting back out to see staff from next week onwards.Monday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Dingwall sale brings lots of joy to charities
story: CHARITIES which help Highland cancer patients in their time of need will share a pound, windfall from a special auction in Dingwall.The event at Dingwall Auction Mart had originally been put together to raise funds for Beauly mother-of-two Roz Paterson who had been aiming to secure pound, to fund potentially le-saving treatment in the United States,Her condition has proved resistant to several forms of chemotherapy leaving her facing a race against the clock to try and access expensive Car-T cell therapy in Boston.When it emerged that her treatment will now be funded on the NHS much closer to home, a decision was taken that the mart auction would go ahead ndash with four key Highland charities benefiting instead.Supporters of the Raising for Roz campaign had come up trumps with more than  lots put forward.The go-ahead for the auction provided a welcome boost for Highland Hospice, Marie Curie, MacMillan Nurses and Maggiersquos Highland.The star lot was a wedding package worth pound, which was snapped up by Inverness couple Alison Ireland and Christian Kenway for pound.Auction organiser Willie Matheson hailed the full-house auction a great success. He said: ldquoThe star lot was the wedding package which was quite unique and went to a local girl. That meant a lot to us and a lot to me especially.Monday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: MSP issues plea over Ross shire rail reliability
story: RELIABILITY issues and a lack of investment are hampering the rail network in Ross-shirersquos ability to capitalise on growing passenger demand, an MSP has warned.Kate Forbes, who represents Skye, Lochaber and Badenoch, has called for greater investment after annual passenger figures revealed mixed fortunes for some stations amid a general rise in overall use.Passenger numbers at a number of Ross-shire stations have risen in the past year, with the likes of Dingwalland Kyleamong the big winners.But commuter villages like Beauly and Conon Bridge posted drops of around . per cent ndash amid continuing complaints over train cancellations or services failing to stop when attempting to claw back lost time.And campaigners have been pressing for years for the reintroduction of a section of double track at Lentran between Clachnaharry swing bridge and Beauly station to tackle the issue.Ms Forbes said: ldquoPublic transport needs to be reliable, comfortable and regular. If we want to increase these figures more, ScotRail need to provide more reliable services and a better timetable on the north Highland line ndash especially for those commuting for work.Monday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Parents asked to play their part in dealing with Alness disorder
story: PARENTS in an Easter Ross town are being asked to ensure they know what their children are up to at night following spates of antisocial behaviour which has spurred a fresh police crackdown.Officers say they have spoken to a number of young people in Alness in the presence of their parents following the incidents, which have also prompted an appeal from a local councillor.Police Scotland Easter Ross community policing Inspector Jamie Wilson said: ldquoI would like to thank the local community for their patience whilst we investigate these incidents.ldquoI appreciate that behaviour of this nature is alarming, however I would like to reassure local residents that we are working closely with schools, High Le Highland and partners to reduce and prevent further antisocial behaviour.ldquoWe continue to investigate incidents which have been reported and are following positive lines of enquiry. Those involved will be identied and will either be reported to the procurator fiscal or issued with a Recorded Police Warning as appropriate.ldquoWe will also be issuing parents with antisocial behaviour letters highlighting the conduct of their children in the hope that they may be a positive influence before things escalate.ldquoOver recent weeks we have spoken with several youths regarding their conduct in the presence of their parents. In the main the response has been positive and I would appeal to parents in Alness to support the community by knowing what their children are doing each evening. We will continue to target our resources in the area to address the behaviour of those involved.Backing police action, Councillor Pauline Munrosaid: ldquoThese incidents have caused concern to local residents, particularly where property has been damaged.ldquoI would urge parents to be aware of what their children are up to during the evenings and to discuss where they are going.Nicky Grant, head teacher at Alness Academy, said: ldquoWe are working in partnership with Police Scotland to ensure that our students and parents feel supported, informed and engaged at this time.Anyone with information should contact Police on  or Crimestoppers on  you would prefer to remain anonymous.Back in November, we reported how youth workers in Alness had appealed to people to share concerns with them and also appealed to parents.Monday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Stone
story: Highlighting the "great historic good" the European Structural Fund has brought to Ross-shire, Easter Ross MP Jamie Stone said: "It paid for new airports, roads, economic development and tourism.ldquoWhen I asked the Prime Minister what would replace this she referred me to the Shared Prosperity Fund. We are very scant on the details of a Shared Prosperity Fund."Could I respectfully ask the Prime Minister to ask officials to meet with myself and other interested members of parliament to discuss what this fund might be and how it might apply to areas of the UK such as my constituency.Mrs May said she is currently in the process of consulting on the nature of the Shared Prosperity Fund and the criteria within which it will work "so I will ask relevant officials to meet with the honourable gentleman in the way he has requested",Mr Stone though said afterwards: "It is clear that there is nothing concrete about a Shared Prosperity Fund. This was the third time I have asked for details on the proposed replacement funding and for the third time I have not received an answer."The Highlands cannot rely on hypothetical funding and Theresa Mayrsquos lack of clarity shows she is aware leaving the EU will make my constituency worse off.ldquoThis comes as it is estimated that the Highlands and Islands would have been entitled to approximately pound million in EU funding between -.ldquoLeaving the EU, particularly crashing out as Theresa May seems to be advocating, would be a disaster for my constituency."I am elected to represent my constituentsrsquo interests and given the shortfall in funding that the Highlands would face in the case of Brexit, I cannot support anything that will make them worse off.Your view  Email newsdesk@spp-group, leave a comment or write to us at the address on our letters page.Monday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Unclaimed bikes find new home at Alness Academy
story: UNCLAIMED bicycles have been donated by Police Scotland to a Ross-shire school.The bikes, which have been handed over to Alness Academy, will be used in the schoolrsquos bicycle maintenance programme.Sergeant Calum Reid, of the Alness community policing team, told the Journal: ldquoWe were delighted to donate these bikes to Alness Academy and we are always keen to support the work of the Alness Youth Partnership.The eight bikes had been in long-term storage at Alness police station but never recovered by their owners.Sgt Reid gave them away after hearing about the initiative.He said: ldquoIrsquom sure they will now be put to very good use, teaching young people valuable skills for the future.The bike maintenance scheme is run by the schoolrsquos craft, design and technology department, which teaches pupils how to repair, strip and carry out general maintenance on bikes.The programme is more than just an after-school club to the pupils as they receive a SQA level  qualication after completing the course.Monday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Wester Ross island dream moves a step closer to reality
story: AMBITIOUS plans to transform a remote island off the coast of Wester Ross into a world class visitor destination have moved a step closer.Summer Isles Enterprise have lodged a planning application with Highland Council to rebuild a derelict croft house at the Ardnagoine settlement on Tanera Mor.The island was bought in  by English businessman Ian Wace and his we Saffron for pound million and the couple have embarked on a four-year plan to transform it into a retreat for up to  paying guests.Former co-owner of Tanera, Lizzie Williams, who is working with the new owners to realise their dream, said five properties on the island were now occupied by members of a team working on buildings on the island.The latest plans are to restore and convert the croft into a two-bedroom dwelling linked by a conservatory. The site overlooks Badentarbet Bay and the two ruins appear to have originally been one long building.In the consultation documents, agents Reynolds Architecture say the design of the building has involved historical research and where possible, reclaimed materials will be used in the construction work.An access track to the south of the dwelling would allow access to the site.This is the sixth property to be restored on the island which once had a population of .The intention is to rebuild the settlements of Ardnagoine, Tigh-an-Quay an Garadheancal to create three distinct clusters which will allow for three dferent groups of guests to occupy the island at any one time, or for one large party to take over the entire island.As well as providing jobs in the reconstruction of the ruins on the island, there will be long-term employment for local people servicing and maintaining the facilities.ldquoWe have already carried out work on the quarry cottage, the byre, the kitchen croft and a cafe pub by the shore and Mathesons, another ruin, has been converted into a cottage, ldquo said Ms Williams.ldquoWe bring tradesmen and other workers over from Achiltibuie and Ullapool on a daily basis and workers who travel from further afield stay on the island and go home at weekends.ldquoWe are looking to restore up to another  properties on the island.Monday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies. title: Winning efforts in Highland Hospcie competition
story: YOUNG business brains from across the Highlands were put to the test in a competition which sharpened their entrepreneurial skills and raised money for a deserving cause.Teams of six from local schools competed in the event organised by Highland Hospice.Secondary school pupils took each other on for the Young Highland Apprentice title, while primary children battled it out in their own junior event.The aim in both cases was to come up with a new product or service that could be sold to raise funds for the hospice.Pupils from Lochardil Primary School in Inverness triumphed in the junior category for their Rocks and Crosses game, a version of noughts and crosses using hand-painted rocks which comes with a gt bag that doubles up as the game board.Sales raised a total of pound. and saw the school crowned winners after a presentation at Inverness College UHI this week.Judges said they were impressed with their business acumen as well as their knowledge of the hospice and the work it does.Winning pound for their school courtesy of event sponsors Tailormade Moves, teacher Muriel Murray said: ldquoTheyrsquore delighted, really proud of themselves.ldquoItrsquos good to see their hard work recognised.In the older age category it was a team from Fortrose Academy who were triumphant, and Tain Royal Academy were runners-up.A team of fth years ran a whole iety of fundraising events between September and January that allowed them to present the hospice with a cheque for pound..Speaking about the impact of the competition as a whole, hospice community fundraiser Katie Gibb said: ldquoAs Highland Hospice is a vital service for the whole of the Highland community, this is a great way for us to raise awareness about our services within the younger generation.Monday  Feb  : AMBy using this site, you agree we can set and use cookies.
